paper_description: Ambuehl, Bernheim & Lusardi, 'Evaluating Deliberative Competence'. Two online RCTs (MTurk) testing whether a financial literacy intervention (Rule of 72 heuristic + framing rhetoric) improves compounding knowledge and financial decision-making.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: ITT effect of full financial literacy treatment (Full vs Control) on compounding test score (score_compounding, 0-5 scale), Experiment A individual-level sample, OLS with clustered SE at individual level.

claim_object.treatment_concept: Full financial literacy intervention (Rule of 72 heuristic + framing rhetoric video)
claim_object.estimand_concept: ITT effect of full treatment on compounding test score (Full vs Control)

baseline_groups.expected_sign_notes: Treatment should improve compounding knowledge; coefficient on Full (vs Control) expected positive.

baseline_specs.label: Table4-Col1-ExpA (canonical primary)
baseline_specs.notes: Primary baseline for G1. OLS ITT, cluster SE at id. Matches surface spec 'baseline__table4_col1_expA'. Runner used spec_id='baseline' (alias for the primary).

baseline_specs.label: Table4-Col2-ExpB (secondary baseline)
baseline_specs.notes: Secondary baseline using Experiment B replication sample. Same outcome concept and estimand on independent sample.

baseline_groups.surface_alignment_notes: Surface planned spec_id 'baseline__table4_col1_expA'; runner used 'baseline' as the primary alias. The executed run_0001 matches the planned spec perfectly (same N=214, same sample filter, same estimand). No alignment issue.
baseline_groups.missing_notes: Attrition spec skipped by runner: requires full pipeline re-run without multi==0 exclusion. This is documented in SPECIFICATION_SEARCH.md note 3. Not a critical omission.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: ITT effect of full financial literacy treatment on reducing valuation errors between simple and complex frames (negAbsDiff = -|discount_framed - discount_unframed|), Experiment A observation-level data (multiple obs per subject), no-constant OLS with focal Wald test Full==Control.

claim_object.outcome_concept: Financial competence: negative absolute valuation difference (-|discount_framed - discount_unframed|), higher is better
claim_object.treatment_concept: Full financial literacy intervention (Rule of 72 heuristic + framing rhetoric video)
claim_object.estimand_concept: ITT effect of full treatment on reducing valuation errors (Full vs Control, Wald test from nocons model)
claim_object.target_population: Online MTurk participants, Experiment A (sample=='old'), observation-level (subject x price-list)

baseline_groups.expected_sign_notes: Treatment should reduce valuation errors; negAbsDiff = -|error|, so positive contrast (Full - Control) means treatment reduces errors.

baseline_specs.label: Table7-Col1-ExpA (canonical primary)
baseline_specs.notes: Primary baseline for G2. 4-arm no-constant OLS ITT. Reported coefficient is the contrast Full - Control = -22.864 - (-24.088) = 1.224. p=0.605 indicates the Exp A effect is NOT statistically significant. Matches surface spec 'baseline__table7_col1_expA'. Runner used spec_id='baseline' as alias.

baseline_specs.label: Table7-Col2-ExpB (secondary baseline)
baseline_specs.notes: Secondary baseline using Experiment B. Same outcome concept. Full - Control = -18.258 - (-25.673) = 7.415. Exp B shows strong significant improvement.

baseline_groups.surface_alignment_notes: Same alias pattern as G1. run_0030 matches the planned primary baseline. Execution is correct.
baseline_groups.missing_notes: Same attrition spec skipped (requires pipeline remanagement). Documented in SPECIFICATION_SEARCH.md.

global_notes: All 69 specs succeeded (run_success=1). No failed rows.

Both baseline groups used 'baseline' as the primary spec_id (alias for the canonical ExpA baseline), with the secondary ExpB baseline using an explicit spec_id. This deviates from the surface's planned spec_ids ('baseline__table4_col1_expA', 'baseline__table7_col1_expA') but the executed specs are substantively correct and match planned sample filters and N.
G2 primary baseline (Exp A) shows p=0.605 (not significant); G2 secondary (Exp B) shows p<0.001 (strongly significant). This asymmetry is substantively important and correctly captured.
Null CIs for many rows: the runner did not compute CI for multi-arm no-constant models or alternative outcome specs. This is an acceptable limitation; scalar SE and p-values are present for all rows.
Surface hash is consistent across all 69 rows: sha256:041c4646c5a78637a0e4e376de7e0cc1d8b9ee062acf774a10779689e5e352bd.
p_value=0.0 for 5 rows (Exp B specs with very large effects) reflects floating-point underflow, not a data error.
Baseline group assignments are correct and consistent with the surface. No adjustments needed.
